data.title: Inversed Letters and Sentences!
data.solution:
"""
Coding is fun... Until it errors - The_ZimaBlue

"""
def inversed_letters(string):
    """(str) -> str

    returns inversed letters in a string.

    >>> inversed_letters('a')
    z
    >>> inversed_letters('z.')
    a.
    >>> inversed_letters('Svool Dliow!')
    Hello World!
    """

    ans = ''

    for char in string:

        if char.isalpha():

            if char.isupper():

                num = ord(char) - 65
                ans += chr((26 - num) + 64)

            else:
                num = ord(char) - 97
                ans += chr((26 - num) + 96)
        else:
            ans += char

    return ans


def inversed_sentences(string):
    """(str) -> str

    Inverses the location of all words in a string.

    >>> inversed_sentences('A')
    A
    >>> inversed_sentences('A B')
    B A
    >>> inversed_sentences('World! Hello')
    Hello World!
    """

    ans = ''
    string = string.split()
    length = len(string)

    for word in range(length):

        if word != length - 1:
            ans += string[length - word - 1] + ' '

        else:
            ans += string[length - word - 1]

    return ans

print(inversed_sentences(inversed_letters(input())))

Storyline:
You have to decrypt a message for the army.

The Problem:
You have to do these steps in any order:
- Inverse every word such that the first word is last and the last word is first.(Hello World!) -> World! Hello
- Inverse each letter such that 'a's will become 'z's and 'b's will become 'y's and so on...

Notes:
Your code must switch the letters regardless of case
Your code must move words such that if a comma or exclamation mark or etc.(if not separated by space) will be moved with the word
Input
Line 1: A message(String)
Output
Line 1: A decoded message(String)
Constraints
0 < Length of message < 101
Example
Input
Dliow! Svool
Output
Hello World!
